clusters.title: Japanese emperor approves Takaichi as first female prime minister

items.title: Japanese emperor approves Takaichi as first female prime minister
items.standfirst: Japan’s Emperor Naruhito has officially appointed Sanae Takaichi as prime minister.
items.content: Japan’s Emperor Naruhito has officially appointed Sanae Takaichi as prime minister.

items.title: Japan's first female prime minister plays heavy metal on drums to let off steam
items.standfirst: Sanae Takaichi is the first woman chosen to serve as Japan's prime minister. She favors a strong military, a strong economy — and a strong drum riff.
items.content: Sanae Takaichi is the first woman chosen to serve as Japan's prime minister. She favors a strong military, a strong economy — and a strong drum riff.

items.title: 5 things to know about Sanae Takaichi, Japan's first female prime minister
items.standfirst: Japan ranks low in gender equality among developed nations. The first woman to lead the country is an ultraconservative who cites Margaret Thatcher as a role model. She also loves heavy metal.
items.content: Japan ranks low in gender equality among developed nations. The first woman to lead the country is an ultraconservative who cites Margaret Thatcher as a role model. She also loves heavy metal.(Image credit: Kim Kyung-Hoon)

items.title: Japan's first female leader: A historic moment with caveats
items.standfirst: Sanae Takaichi, Japan's first female prime minister, is not known for progressive views on women's equality.
items.content: Sanae Takaichi, Japan's first female prime minister, is not known for progressive views on women's equality.

items.title: Video: Who is Sanae Takaichi, Japan’s first female prime minister
items.standfirst: Japanese parliamentarians have elected the country’s first female prime minister.
items.content: Japanese parliamentarians have elected the country’s first female prime minister.

items.title: Japan has its first female prime minister, but not all women are celebrating
items.standfirst: Lawmakers in Japan elected hardline conservative Sanae Takaichi as prime minister on Tuesday, making her the first woman in modern times to lead the key U.S. ally.
items.content: Lawmakers in Japan elected hardline conservative Sanae Takaichi as prime minister on Tuesday, making her the first woman in modern times to lead the key U.S. ally.

items.title: Japan votes in country's first ever female PM
items.standfirst: Japan's parliament has voted in the country's first ever female prime minister.
items.content: Japan's parliament has voted in the country's first ever female prime minister.

ai_summary: Sanae Takaichi was officially appointed as Japan's prime minister by Emperor Naruhito.
She is known for conservative views and cites Margaret Thatcher as a role model.
Takaichi is the first woman to lead Japan in modern times.
She is a supporter of a strong military and economy.
Some women are not celebrating her election.

items.title: Louvre heist losses put at almost €90m as museum’s head prepares to face MPs
items.standfirst: Police continue to search for the criminal gang behind the brazen robbery targeting France’s crown jewelsThe financial loss from France’s most dramatic heist in decades has been put at nearly €90m as the head of the Louvre prepared to face difficult questions over how thieves were able to steal priceless jewellery in broad daylight.As police continued to search for the criminal gang behind the brazen robbery on Sunday, the Paris prosecutor Laure Beccuau told the broadcaster RTL that the museum’s curator had estimated the losses at about €88m (£76m). Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Louvre heist losses estimated at 88 million euros
items.standfirst: The losses caused by the daylight robbery of several pieces of Napoleonic jewellery from the Louvre Sunday have been estimated at some 88 million euros, Paris prosecutor Laure Beccuau said Tuesday.
items.content: The losses caused by the daylight robbery of several pieces of Napoleonic jewellery from the Louvre Sunday have been estimated at some 88 million euros, Paris prosecutor Laure Beccuau said Tuesday.

ai_summary: Thieves stole jewelry from the Louvre Museum in a daylight robbery.
The estimated value of the stolen items is €88 million, according to the Paris prosecutor.
The museum's curator provided the loss estimate.
Police are investigating the theft and searching for the suspects.
The heist involved several pieces of Napoleonic jewelry.

items.title: JD Vance expresses ‘great optimism’ over Gaza ceasefire deal during Israel visit
items.standfirst: US vice-president to visit Netanyahu while Hamas joins talks in Cairo meant to iron out differencesThe US vice-president, JD Vance, expressed “great optimism” over the Gaza truce plan which he described as “durable” and “going better than expected”, during a visit to Israel on Tuesday, two days after Israeli airstrikes killed 26 Palestinians.Vance’s trip, as part of the Trump administration’s efforts to strengthen the ceasefire agreement, comes as Hamas officials joined talks in Cairo meant to bridge outstanding differences with Israel. Continue reading...
items.content: US vice-president to visit Netanyahu while Hamas joins talks in Cairo meant to iron out differencesThe US vice-president, JD Vance, expressed “great optimism” over the Gaza truce plan which he described as “durable” and “going better than expected”, during a visit to Israel on Tuesday, two days after Israeli airstrikes killed 26 Palestinians.Vance’s trip, as part of the Trump administration’s efforts to strengthen the ceasefire agreement, comes as Hamas officials joined talks in Cairo meant to bridge outstanding differences with Israel. items.title: What to take away from JD Vance's press conference on the Gaza ceasefire
items.standfirst: US Vice President JD Vance tried to soothe fears that the ceasefire signed by Israel and Hamas was under strain, telling a press conference in southern Israel Tuesday that the truce was going better than he had anticipated. Here are some of the main points the vice president made in his press conference.
items.content: US Vice President JD Vance tried to soothe fears that the ceasefire signed by Israel and Hamas was under strain, telling a press conference in southern Israel Tuesday that the truce was going better than he had anticipated. Here are some of the main points the vice president made in his press conference.

items.title: Vance expresses optimism and preaches patience in Israel as ceasefire worries grow
items.standfirst: Vice President JD Vance expressed cautious optimism Tuesday that peace will hold between Israel and Hamas despite recent violence that threatened the fragile U.S.-brokered ceasefire.“What we’ve seen the past week gives me great optimism the ceasefire is going to hold, and if we get from where we were a week ago to a long-term, durable peace between Israel and Gaza, there are going to be hills and valleys,” Vance said at a news conference to announce the opening of a civilian military coope
items.content: Vice President JD Vance expressed cautious optimism Tuesday that peace will hold between Israel and Hamas despite recent violence that threatened the fragile U.S.-brokered ceasefire.“What we’ve seen the past week gives me great optimism the ceasefire is going to hold, and if we get from where we were a week ago to a long-term, durable peace between Israel and Gaza, there are going to be hills and valleys,” Vance said at a news conference to announce the opening of a civilian military coope

items.title: Gaza tries to rebuild amid fragile ceasefire
items.standfirst: With the fragile ceasefire still holding, Gazans try to rebuild after two years of continuous bombing. At the same time, concern grows regarding the fragile US-brokered peace deal, following a flare f tension between Israel and Hamas. Said concerns have prompted a visit from US Vice President JD Vance.
items.content: With the fragile ceasefire still holding, Gazans try to rebuild after two years of continuous bombing. At the same time, concern grows regarding the fragile US-brokered peace deal, following a flare f tension between Israel and Hamas. Said concerns have prompted a visit from US Vice President JD Vance.

items.title: Vice President JD Vance's visit to Israel is a US sign of 'concern' regarding fragile ceasefire
items.standfirst: US President JD Vance is visiting Israel today as tensions flare up with Hamas, weakening an already fragile US-brokered ceasefire. The visit takes place as negotiations regarding phase two of the ceasefire stall. FRANCE 24's Kethevane Gorjestani tells us more.
items.content: US President JD Vance is visiting Israel today as tensions flare up with Hamas, weakening an already fragile US-brokered ceasefire. The visit takes place as negotiations regarding phase two of the ceasefire stall. FRANCE 24's Kethevane Gorjestani tells us more.

ai_summary: Vice President JD Vance expressed optimism about the Gaza ceasefire during a visit to Israel.

His visit followed a flare-up of violence between Israel and Hamas.
Hamas officials joined talks in Cairo to address differences.
Vance urged patience regarding the return of hostages' remains.

items.standfirst: White House announcement walks back US president’s announcement of a meeting in Hungary; official says secretary Rubio and foreign minister Lavrov had ‘productive call’US shelves plans for Trump-Putin talks in BudapestThe Central Intelligence Agency is providing the bulk of the intelligence used to carry out the controversial lethal air strikes by the Trump administration against small, fast-going boats in the Caribbean Sea suspected of carrying drugs from Venezuela, according to three sources familiar with the operations.Experts say the agency’s central role means much of the evidence used to select which alleged smugglers to kill on the open sea will almost certainly remain secret. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Ecuador releases survivor of US strike on alleged drug-trafficking submarine
items.standfirst: Officials say they have no evidence man had committed a crime, after Trump called people on submarine ‘terrorists’CIA playing ‘most important part’ in US strikes in the Caribbean, sources sayEcuador has released a man who survived a US strike on a suspected drug-trafficking submarine, after finding no evidence that he had committed a crime, the attorney general’s office has said.The United States has deployed warships to the Caribbean off the coast of Venezuela since August, attacking mostly boats that US authorities said were running drugs. Continue reading...
items.content: Officials say they have no evidence man had committed a crime, after Trump called people on submarine ‘terrorists’CIA playing ‘most important part’ in US strikes in the Caribbean, sources sayEcuador has released a man who survived a US strike on a suspected drug-trafficking submarine, after finding no evidence that he had committed a crime, the attorney general’s office has said.The United States has deployed warships to the Caribbean off the coast of Venezuela since August, attacking mostly boats that US authorities said were running drugs. Continue reading...

items.title: Ecuador releases survivor of US strike on 'drug sub' in Caribbean
items.standfirst: Ecuadorian officials say they found no evidence the man had committed a crime, and so had freed him.
items.content: Ecuadorian officials say they found no evidence the man had committed a crime, and so had freed him.

items.title: Ecuador releases survivor of U.S. strike on alleged "narco sub"
items.standfirst: Ecuador released a man who survived a U.S. strike on a suspected drug-trafficking vessel after finding no evidence that he had committed a crime, officials said.
items.content: Ecuador released a man who survived a U.S. strike on a suspected drug-trafficking vessel after finding no evidence that he had committed a crime, officials said.

items.title: CIA playing ‘most important part’ in US strikes in the Caribbean, sources say
items.standfirst: Exclusive: Sources say the agency is providing real-time intelligence collected by satellites and signal interceptsEcuador releases survivor of US strike on alleged drug-trafficking submarineThe Central Intelligence Agency is providing the bulk of the intelligence used to carry out the controversial lethal airstrikes by the Trump administration against small, fast-going boats in the Caribbean Sea suspected of carrying drugs from Venezuela, according to three sources familiar with the operations. Experts say the agency’s central role means much of the evidence used to select which alleged smugglers to kill on the open sea will almost certainly remain secret.The agency’s central role in the boat strikes has not previously been disclosed. Donald Trump confirmed last Wednesday that he had authorized covert CIA action in Venezuela, but not what the agency would be doing. Continue reading...
items.content: Exclusive: Sources say the agency is providing real-time intelligence collected by satellites and signal interceptsEcuador releases survivor of US strike on alleged drug-trafficking submarineThe Central Intelligence Agency is providing the bulk of the intelligence used to carry out the controversial lethal airstrikes by the Trump administration against small, fast-going boats in the Caribbean Sea suspected of carrying drugs from Venezuela, according to three sources familiar with the operations. Experts say the agency’s central role means much of the evidence used to select which alleged smugglers to kill on the open sea will almost certainly remain secret.The agency’s central role in the boat strikes has not previously been disclosed. Donald Trump confirmed last Wednesday that he had authorized covert CIA action in Venezuela, but not what the agency would be doing. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Ecuador released a survivor of a US strike on a suspected drug-trafficking submarine.
Officials found no evidence the man had committed a crime.
The US has been attacking boats in the Caribbean suspected of carrying drugs.
The CIA is playing a key role in US strikes in the Caribbean.

items.standfirst: Sometimes former presidents do go to jail.

items.title: Sarkozy in jail: What are French prisons really like?
items.standfirst: With Nicolas Sarkozy now incarcerated and behind bars at the “Prison de la Santé”, we take a look at what makes this Parisian prison unique. We also dive into the different kinds of French prisons and how they are plagued by overcrowding. Finally, we find out what the former French president took with him to prison.
items.content: With Nicolas Sarkozy now incarcerated and behind bars at the “Prison de la Santé”, we take a look at what makes this Parisian prison unique. We also dive into the different kinds of French prisons and how they are plagued by overcrowding. Finally, we find out what the former French president took with him to prison.

items.title: Warner Bros Discovery considers sale as potential buyers show interest
items.standfirst: Netflix, Comcast and Paramount Skydance are reportedly among possible bidders in sale that could shake up industryWarner Bros Discovery is considering putting the entire company up for sale, a move that could see huge restructuring in an industry that has seen ripples of changes since Donald Trump took office.The company initially said in June that it would split up Warner Bros and Discovery, after the two companies were merged in 2022. But after receiving “unsolicited interest … from multiple parties for both the entire company and Warner Bros”, according to a statement released on Monday, the entire company could be up for a transaction. The company could also split up Warner Bros and Discovery, selling off Discovery while merging Warner Bros with another company, it said. Continue reading...
items.content: Netflix, Comcast and Paramount Skydance are reportedly among possible bidders in sale that could shake up industryWarner Bros Discovery is considering putting the entire company up for sale, a move that could see huge restructuring in an industry that has seen ripples of changes since Donald Trump took office.The company initially said in June that it would split up Warner Bros and Discovery, after the two companies were merged in 2022. But after receiving “unsolicited interest … from multiple parties for both the entire company and Warner Bros”, according to a statement released on Monday, the entire company could be up for a transaction. The company could also split up Warner Bros and Discovery, selling off Discovery while merging Warner Bros with another company, it said. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Former president organised stage-managed departure from his Paris home before becoming first French postwar leader to be jailedWhat can Sarkozy expect in La Santé prison?The former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has been jailed in Paris, after a court sentenced him to five years for criminal conspiracy over a scheme to obtain election campaign funds from the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi.France’s rightwing president between 2007 and 2012 is the first former head of an EU country to serve time in prison, and the first French postwar leader to go behind bars. Continue reading...
items.content: Former president organised stage-managed departure from his Paris home before becoming first French postwar leader to be jailedWhat can Sarkozy expect in La Santé prison?The former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has been jailed in Paris, after a court sentenced him to five years for criminal conspiracy over a scheme to obtain election campaign funds from the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi.France’s rightwing president between 2007 and 2012 is the first former head of an EU country to serve time in prison, and the first French postwar leader to go behind bars. Continue reading...

items.title: What is the 'Lybian case' that has led to Nicolas Sarkozy's conviction?
items.standfirst: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy is starting a 5-year prison sentence after he was found guilty in the so-called 'Lybian Case'. Prosecutors said his aides, acting in Sarkozy's name, struck a deal with Kadhafi in 2005 to illegally fund his victorious presidential election bid two years later.
items.content: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy is starting a 5-year prison sentence after he was found guilty in the so-called 'Lybian Case'. Prosecutors said his aides, acting in Sarkozy's name, struck a deal with Kadhafi in 2005 to illegally fund his victorious presidential election bid two years later.

items.title: Supporters and opponents of Nicolas Sarkozy disagree on prison sentence
items.standfirst: Former French President's Nicolas Sarkozy's prison sentence has been very divisive in France. While supporters argue it was politically motivated, opponents accuse Sarkozy of double-standards, with the leader calling for a tougher justice system until it comes to his own behaviour. FRANCE 24's Angela Diffley looks into it for us.
items.content: Former French President's Nicolas Sarkozy's prison sentence has been very divisive in France. While supporters argue it was politically motivated, opponents accuse Sarkozy of double-standards, with the leader calling for a tougher justice system until it comes to his own behaviour. FRANCE 24's Angela Diffley looks into it for us.

items.title: Nicolas Sarkozy prison sentence divides France
items.standfirst: As former French President Nicolas Sarkozy starts to serve his prison sentence, supporters claim the conviction was politically motivated. But for 6 out of 10 French people, the decision is fair. The ex-leader was found guilty of seeking to acquire funding from Moamer Kadhafi's Libya for the campaign that saw him elected.
items.content: As former French President Nicolas Sarkozy starts to serve his prison sentence, supporters claim the conviction was politically motivated. But for 6 out of 10 French people, the decision is fair. The ex-leader was found guilty of seeking to acquire funding from Moamer Kadhafi's Libya for the campaign that saw him elected.

items.title: Will Darmanin's Sarkozy visit shed light on poor prison conditions: overcrowding, healthcare access?
items.standfirst: Nicolas Sarkozy entered the Elysee Palace in 2007 boasting hyperactive energy and a vision to transform France, but lost office after just one term. He entered prison on Tuesday after a judge sentenced him last month to five years for criminal conspiracy over a scheme to secure funding for his 2007 campaign from Libya's then-leader Muammar Gaddafi. For a closer look at the notorious prison complex where the former president has been incarcerated, Delano D'Souza welcomes Clémence Bouchart, Head of Research and Publication at Prison Insider.
items.content: Nicolas Sarkozy entered the Elysee Palace in 2007 boasting hyperactive energy and a vision to transform France, but lost office after just one term. He entered prison on Tuesday after a judge sentenced him last month to five years for criminal conspiracy over a scheme to secure funding for his 2007 campaign from Libya's then-leader Muammar Gaddafi. For a closer look at the notorious prison complex where the former president has been incarcerated, Delano D'Souza welcomes Clémence Bouchart, Head of Research and Publication at Prison Insider.

items.title: What can Sarkozy expect in La Santé prison and what has he taken with him?
items.standfirst: Former French president will reportedly be held in isolation and has a copy of The Count of Monte Cristo for companyPerhaps France’s most fabled jail, La Santé – where the former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has begun a five-year term for criminal conspiracy to raise campaign funds from Libya – is the last remaining prison inside the Paris city limits.Located in the southern Montparnasse district of the capital, it opened in 1867 and was the scene of at least 40 executions, the last in 1972. Partially closed for renovation in 2014, the prison reopened five years later and houses more than 1,100 inmates. Continue reading...
items.content: Former French president will reportedly be held in isolation and has a copy of The Count of Monte Cristo for companyPerhaps France’s most fabled jail, La Santé – where the former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has begun a five-year term for criminal conspiracy to raise campaign funds from Libya – is the last remaining prison inside the Paris city limits.Located in the southern Montparnasse district of the capital, it opened in 1867 and was the scene of at least 40 executions, the last in 1972. Partially closed for renovation in 2014, the prison reopened five years later and houses more than 1,100 inmates. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy has begun a five-year prison sentence.
He was convicted of criminal conspiracy related to campaign funding.
The funding came from the regime of Muammar Gaddafi.
Sarkozy is the first postwar French leader to be jailed.
The sentence has divided France, with supporters and opponents reacting.
